title: Old titles are not hidden in reports with limited disclosure

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
When a report is made public it shows all activity that took place in that report. This includes showing if the title of the report was changed and what it was changed from. 

This could cause information to be public that the business may not wish to make public if the person that created the report put a very descriptive title.
For Example
https://hackerone.com/reports/140392
This report was changed to only say a subdomain contained a cj vuln but the previous title which is still visible in the activity specifies the exact subdomain that was originally included in the title.

@jthetechguy, we haven't forgotten about you. ;)

Thanks for the report! While we feel this is just additional defense-in-depth at ensuring our "limited disclosure" feature fully covers all possible fields and isn't dealing with any immediate risk, it is indeed valuable and could have potentially caused real problems for a customer if they were expecting everything to be redacted, including previous report titles. As such, we are awarding our minimum bounty for this finding.

Happy hacking! Do let us know if you find anything else like this or otherwise!

Severe: Any bug that might grant unauthorized access to confidential bug descriptions.

activities.message:
Hi @jthetechguy,

Sorry for the belated response. We dropped the ball here.

Evaluating reports is always tricky, and I can see that you may disagree with the bounty decision.

We had a tough time deciding if this was a real issue in the first place. It's not common for titles to contain sensitive information, and title changes are usually reserved for things like typo fixes or better phrasing. It rarely happens that a title needs censoring.

On the other hand, we do see a minor benefit in hiding the title or non-participants. In addition, because this was a relatively easy change to make, we decided to go for the minor improvement.

I hope this sheds some light on the issue from our perspective. Thank you for the suggested scope change. I'll make sure it's noted and will see if this is something we want to clarify upon.

activities.message:
@siebejan I realize this is an old report but I was reading through some recent reports and came across this one https://hackerone.com/reports/188719

"Our policy describes that HackerOne awards $10,000 for any vulnerability that might grant unauthorized access to confidential bug descriptions. Although HackerOne doesn’t believe this meets that exact description, HackerOne cannot guarantee what kind of information hackers provide in report titles. Because of that, we decided to still award a $10,000 bounty. However, anything other than the report title of resolved bugs were not exposed through this vulnerability."

Im curious why that report qualified given your previous statement of 
"We had a tough time deciding if this was a real issue in the first place. It's not common for titles to contain sensitive information, and title changes are usually reserved for things like typo fixes or better phrasing. It rarely happens that a title needs censoring."

Has the criteria changed?

activities.message:
Hi @jthetechguy,

There are a couple of differences between this report and #188719 that resulted in the difference in bounty amount.

* This report only affects publicly disclosed reports. Moreover, both the hacker and the team can view the entire report, with activities, before it goes public. There is no element of surprise, so to say.
* Moreover, the above means that there is a significant reduced set of reports that are potentially affected. Compare that to #188719, where essentially *any* report is a potential target.
* Title changes are used to fix typos, or to clarify the report as time goes on. It is rarely used to hide information.

I hope you find this a satisfactory answer. If there's anything else I can do for you, please let me know!
